thread.title: Blue Hens face tough task vs. William & Mary
thread.title_full: Blue Hens face tough task vs. William & Mary

title: Blue Hens face tough task vs. William & Mary
text:
Blue Hens face tough task vs. William & Mary 5 THINGS TO KNOW: William & Mary at Blue Hens Sponsored by Tribe (2-1) vs. Blue Hens (1-3) 7:30, Saturday, Oct. 3 No. 1 This is pivotal 
Even before preseason camp started, the William & Mary game shaped up as potentially pivotal for Delaware. That has not changed. A victory over a very good William & Mary team would give the young Hens major momentum they could carry through October. A loss will quickly make reaching the NCAA playoffs very difficult and even put a winning season in jeopardy. William Bretzger/The News Journal No. 2 Thrown for a loss Delaware ranks 122 nd among 123 FCS teams with 77.5 passing yards per game. Only Cal Poly (57.3) is worse. Delaware has run the ball well, including with QB Joe Walker. The Hens need cleaner throws and fewer drops, to have a chance against William & Mary. The Tribe is allowing just 87.7 yards rushing per game on average, best in the CAA. All 15 of Delaware's first downs against North Carolina last week came on running plays. William & Mary Athletics No. 3 Rhodes to ruin 
The Butkus Award annual recognizes college football's best linebacker. There is only one FCS-level player on the watch list for the award, and he happens to be William & Mary's Luke Rhodes . The senior is also just the second two-year captain in 122 years of football at William & Mary. "Rhodes looks like he makes everybody around him better," Delaware coach Dave Brock said. Some of them are already exceptional, especially safety DeAndre Houston-Carson (22 tackles and an interception) and DT Tyler Claytor (7.5 sacks in his last nine games). The News Journal No. 4 For starters A loss to William & Mary would leave Delaware 1-4 for the first time since 1967 - coach Tubby Raymond's second season. Like this one, that team started numerous sophomores - freshmen were not eligible then - and became the foundation for UD teams that, from 1968 to 1976, won at least eight games every year, captured two national titles and lost in a national title. William Bretzger/The News Journal No. 5 Hall of fame game 
Delaware inducts its annual Athletic Hall of Fame class Friday night and introduces the 10 honorees at halftime Saturday. Five of them played football - Omar Cuff , the 2004-07 running back; long-time offensive coordinator Ted Kempski, also a former UD quarterback; George Schmitt, the cornerback who played all 16 games with the then-St. Louis Cardinals as an NFL rookie in 1983 before an injury ended his career; Bruce Fad, a safety on Delaware's 1968-70 football teams who also excelled in baseball; and Joe Lank, Delaware's Outstanding Senior Athlete in 1952 after starring in football, baseball and as a discus and javelin thrower. Those five will be honorary game captains. Kempski still attends most UD practices, keeping a close eye on the offense. Joining them are volleyball's Stephanie Barry Courtney, tennis/basketball standout Ken Dill, basketball star and shot-putter Sarah Gause Flanders, field hockey's Leah Geib Maceroli and Steve Shaw from lacrosse. William & Mary Athletics KEVIN TRESOLINI'S PICK William & Mary 23, Delaware 16 On the air: Listen to Kevin Tresolini on WDSD-FM (94.7) with Scott Klatzkin and Matt Janus on the pregame show prior to each University of Delaware football broadcast. By Kevin Tresolini, @kevintresolini Kevin Tresolini , The News Journal 1:15 p.m. EDT October 2, 2015 Buy Photo Delaware quarterback Joe Walker carries for a gain in the second quarter against Lafayette earlier this season. (Photo: WILLIAM BRETZGER/THE NEWS JOURNAL) Buy Photo 1 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
NEWARK William & Mary arrives at Delaware Stadium on Saturday with a double-barreled reputation upholding its No. 25 national ranking in FCS. 
The Tribe is extremely stout throughout on defense. It also exhibits an offense that, behind a formidable front, can move the football in a myriad of ways. 
In many ways, that makes William & Mary exactly the type of football team Delaware aspires to be. 
The Blue Hens aren’t there yet, and William & Mary will likely make their attempt to continue to develop quite a challenge in the 7:30 p.m. Delaware Stadium matchup. It will be televised nationally on the NBC Sports Network. 
“They play exceptionally hard and they’re very, very physical,” Delaware coach Dave Brock said of the Tribe. “I think they play great complimentary football, great team football. They take the ball away, they don’t give it away. They run the ball, they stop the run. They play good special teams.’’ 
Coming off a confidence-building effort at FBS North Carolina, which pulled away late for a 41-14 win, the Blue Hens find themselves at a critical juncture. A winning season and their ultimate goal – making the NCAA playoffs – may ride on this outcome for Delaware (1-3 overall, 0-1 CAA). 
William & Mary (2-1, 1-0) shut out Stony Brook 21-0 last week. 
“It’s William & Mary. There always ready to play,” said Delaware senior defensive lineman and team captain David Tinsley after a spirited practice session. “We know it’s going to be a line-of-scrimmage game and that’s what we pride ourselves on. Our offensive and defensive lines need to be ready to play. We just have to do our job, knock it back on the line.’’ 
The Tribe and Blue Hens are each among the CAA leaders in rushing offense and rushing defense, with Delaware having gained a season-high 279 ground yards last week at UNC. Stony Brook had averaged 286.5 ground yards per game before being limited to 64 by William & Mary. 
“They look like they have as good a football team as they’ve had in a while,” Brock said. “They’re certainly playing great football and I can’t imagine they’re going to lack for confidence after coming off a shutout and doing what they did to Stony Brook’s defense. I think everybody in this league knows how good they are.” 
But Delaware has struggled to get its passing game untracked, with freshman quarterback Joe Walker having completed just four passes in two of the last three games, which adds to Saturday’s challenge. 
Throwing the football has never been a problem for William & Mary, whose 36th-year coach Jimmye Laycock’s has long been singled out for his offensive acumen, particularly with his passing attack. The fact that William & Mary can run the football so well makes their passing game even more dangerous. 
Tailback Mikal Abdul-Saboor had rushed for 100 yards or more in seven straight games, and 15 overall, before last week. When he went out with an injury against Stony Brook, junior Kendell Anderson stepped in and gained 191 yards on 19 carries with two touchdowns. 
William & Mary junior quarterback Steve Cluley is No. 2 in the CAA in passing efficiency while completing 64 percent of his passes with six touchdowns and just one interception. Tinsley said the Tribe will try to lull the Hens by pounding the football on the ground and then hit them with a clever pass play. 
Despite the Blue Hens’ youth – 16 starters and 33 of the 46 who played last week at North Carolina were freshmen and sophomores – Laycock said Delaware cannot be underestimated. 
“Delaware’s Delaware,” Laycock said. “They’re always talented, they always play hard, they’re always good. They’re especially tough to play up there in Newark. We know what we’re getting into.” 
Contact Kevin Tresolini at ktresolini@delawareonline.com . Follow on Twitter @kevintresolini. 
5 THINGS TO WATCH 
1. This is pivotal 
Even before preseason camp started, the William & Mary game shaped up as potentially pivotal for Delaware. That has not changed. A victory over a very good William & Mary team would give the young Hens major momentum they could carry through October. A loss will quickly make reaching the NCAA playoffs very difficult and even put a winning season in jeopardy. 
2. Thrown for a loss 
Delaware ranks 122nd among 123 FCS teams with 77.5 passing yards per game. Only Cal Poly (57.3) is worse. Delaware has run the ball well, including with QB Joe Walker. The Hens need cleaner throws and fewer drops, to have a chance against William & Mary. The Tribe is allowing just 87.7 yards rushing per game on average, best in the CAA. All 15 of Delaware’s first downs against North Carolina last week came on running plays. 
3. Rhodes to ruin 
The Butkus Award annual recognizes college football’s best linebacker. There is only one FCS-level player on the watch list for the award, and he happens to be William & Mary’s Luke Rhodes. The senior is also just the second two-year captain in 122 years of football at William & Mary. “Rhodes looks like he makes everybody around him better,” Delaware coach Dave Brock said. Some of them are already exceptional, especially safety DeAndre Houston-Carson (22 tackles and an interception) and DT Tyler Claytor (7.5 sacks in his last nine games). 
4. For starters 
A loss to William & Mary would leave Delaware 1-4 for the first time since 1967 – coach Tubby Raymond’s second season. Like this one, that team started numerous sophomores – freshmen were not eligible then – and became the foundation for UD teams that, from 1968 to 1976, won at least eight games every year, captured two national titles and lost in a national title. 
5. Hall of fame game 
Delaware inducts its annual Athletic Hall of Fame class Friday night and introduces the 10 honorees at halftime Saturday. Five of them played football – Omar Cuff, the 2004-07 running back; long-time offensive coordinator Ted Kempski, also a former UD quarterback; George Schmitt, the cornerback who played all 16 games with the then-St. Louis Cardinals as an NFL rookie in 1983 before an injury ended his career; Bruce Fad, a safety on Delaware’s 1968-70 football teams who also excelled in baseball; and Joe Lank, Delaware’s Outstanding Senior Athlete in 1952 after starring in football, baseball and as a discus and javelin thrower. Those five will be honorary game captains. Kempski still attends most UD practices, keeping a close eye on the offense. Joining them are volleyball’s Stephanie Barry Courtney, tennis/basketball standout Ken Dill, basketball star and shot-putter Sarah Gause Flanders, field hockey’s Leah Geib Maceroli and Steve Shaw from lacrosse. 
Prediction 
William & Mary 23, Delaware 16 
On the air: Listen to Kevin Tresolini on WDSD-FM (94.7) with Scott Klatzkin and Matt Janus on the pregame show prior to each Delaware football broadcast. 1 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://delonline.us/1RksjTb TOP VIDEOS
